awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Harnessing Complex Dynamics of Coupled Mechanical-Electrical System for an Improved Vibration Energy Harvesting
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to acquire a fundamental understanding of physics in energy capturing devices where vibrational energy is converted into electrical power. The focus of the research will be on maximizing energy capture in these devices by formulating an integrated approach to leverage complex dynamics of vibration energy harvesting mechanisms and nonlinear electrical circuitry needed to capture the energy. The state-of-the-art formulations exploit the nonlinearities in dynamics of either mechanical side (with unrealistic circuits) or electrical side (with simple linear devices) but do not exploit them in an integrated manner. By providing accurate guidelines to design and deploy multimodal, nonlinear energy harvesting systems, this research will significantly promote the development of sustainable microelectronics, such as for wireless sensors in structural, mechanical, and biological monitoring applications in various industries. The outreach activities will utilize, in coordination will diversity-serving organizations, the interactive energy harvesting system demonstrators developed in this project to capture local students' interest in science and engineering subjects and higher education pursuits.

While vibration energy harvesting is becoming more feasible, recent research outcomes show that it is critical that basic research issues be addressed before a high performance, high efficiency energy harvesting system can be realized and deployed for myriad applications. Through new, insightful analytical formulations supported by experimental investigations, these research outcomes will guide development of energy harvesting systems that empower future generations of self-sufficient microelectronics, such as the prolific wireless structural health monitoring sensor networks that are otherwise reliant on unsustainable energy resources. The research efforts will bridge the two research bases of device platform dynamics and electrical circuitry formulation to establish new analytical formulations that accommodate the collective device and electrical nonlinearities and multimodal dynamics. This will facilitate rich insight into their ideal integration. Experimental studies will validate the analytical findings and will investigate new piezoelectric energy harvesting systems identified by the theory that set electrical energy-capture benchmarks.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

In recent years, considerable research efforts have focused on enhancing the performance of vibration energy harvesting systems to realize self-powered electric devices. Examples of applications where vibration energy harvesting is viewed as a viable power source include, but are not limited to, structural health monitoring, microelectromechanical systems, biomedical implantable or wearable devices, and unmanned aerial vehicles. While vibration energy harvesting has shown great promise, most research studies focused on the geometry of a single degree-of-freedom mechanical platform connected to passive linear harvesting circuitry. To successfully implement energy harvesting systems in practical applications, nonlinear rectifying and power management circuitry must be interfaced with the mechanical platform to convert the ambient energy to usable power. In addition, further research is necessary to determine how multimodality, nonlinearity, and topology may be harnessed to enhance energy harvesting performance for a broad range of unpredictable external excitations that are found in practice. This grant supports a collaborative research that investigated how nonlinearity, multimodality, and topology may be leveraged in vibration energy harvesting systems to enhance performance. This research uncovered how coupled nonlinearities in multimodal systems could be harnessed to achieve enhanced energy harvesting performance over a broad frequency range (i.e., broadband) and convert it to usable energy. Furthermore, this study produced fundamental insights into how the rich dynamics of coupled nonlinear systems and nontrivial topology could be employed to improve future energy harvesting outcomes. 

Intellectual merit

This research yielded a rigorous theoretical foundation to elucidate how coupled electrical-mechanical nonlinearities, multimodality, and topology influence energy harvesting performance. The development of novel multimodal energy harvesting systems with coupled nonlinearities facilitated the study of how the potential energy profile of multimodal systems can be tailored using critical system parameters to improve peak and broadband harvesting performance. A comprehensive experimental investigation led to the discovery of the impact of higher order harmonics on power output of a vibration energy harvester with coupled nonlinearities. A rigorous theoretical investigation revealed how vibration energy harvesting elements (piezoelectric transducers) can be used to localize energy in a lossless and adaptive manner. In addition, the insights gained into coupled nonlinearities, multimodality, and topology in vibration energy harvesting constitute an intellectual advancement that would serve as a basis for future studies that will further advance the field.

Broader Impact

Energy harvesting systems find various applications in fields where self-powered or sustainable energy sources are desirable. A deeper understanding of coupled electrical-mechanical nonlinearities, multimodal nonlinear dynamics, and topology is essential to achieving the full potential of vibration energy harvesters in practical applications. In addition, multimodality, topology, and nonlinearity can be harnessed in other applications, such as adaptive structures, communication networks, and actuator and sensor networks. The fundamental insights that result from this work could be applied to these applications and others, creating sustainable, intelligent, and high-performing systems that could benefit a wide range of industries, including aerospace, transportation, robotics, civil infrastructure, microelectronics, renewable energy, and wireless communications.

Summary & Conclusions

During the course of this research, we have worked on three major activities, and investigated the influence of multimodality, nonlinearity, and topology on vibration energy harvesting. A summary of the contributions is provided below.

A. We developed a novel hybrid vibration energy harvester consisting of a bistable energy harvester coupled to a linear energy harvester, which leverages nonlinearity and multimodality to improve performance. Numerical investigations elucidated how critical system parameters (e.g., mass and stiffness of the linear harvesting element) can affect system dynamics and be leveraged through advanced design methodologies. In addition, experimental results revealed new insights into how nonlinear dynamics of multimodal systems can affect the energy harvesting output.

B. We developed a novel energy harvesting architecture comprised of two coupled bistable harvesters that significantly enhanced the ability to tailor the system potential energy characteristics and improved broadband harvesting performance. Fundamental insights into the system's coupled nonlinear dynamics revealed system parameters critical to enhanced broadband performance.

C. We developed a theoretical framework for the realization of an adaptive topological piezoelectric metamaterial. It was revealed that resonant electric circuitry can be utilized to achieve path- and frequency- tunable topologically protected wave transmission. Fundamental understandings into the critical system parameters that govern the system's topological characteristics were obtained. A further evaluation provided insight into how increased electromechanical coupling and lattice reconfiguration can be exploited to enhance the frequency range for topological wave propagation and increase achievable energy localization.
